headline: ESPN Secures MLB Streaming, MLB.TV Rights, Netflix Wins Home Run Derby
summary: MLB on Wednesday announced new three-year media rights deals with ESPN, Netflix and NBC reportedly worth $800 million annually.

headline: Competitive Pressure Pulled Down Comcast Corporation (CMCSA) in Q3
summary: Cullen Capital Management, LLC, operating under the name Schafer Cullen Capital Management, Inc. (SCCM), has released its “SCCM Value Equity Strategy” third-quarter investor letter. A copy of the letter can be downloaded here. The US equity market continued the rally in the third quarter, with the S&P 500 returning 8.1% and the Russell 1000 Value surging 5.3%. […]

headline: Netflix Signals It Would Keep Warner Bros. Films in Theaters if Its Bid Succeeds
summary: The company told Warner Bros. Discovery it would honor the studio's theatrical commitments.

headline: Bear of the Day: Comcast (CMCSA)
summary: Although Comcast remains a dominant name in media and connectivity, the company is being squeezed on multiple fronts as its legacy cable and broadband businesses mature and face disruptive competition.

raw.headline: Bear of the Day: Comcast (CMCSA)

headline: Amphenol and Comcast have been highlighted as Zacks Bull and Bear of the Day
summary: Amphenol stands out as a bull with strong margins, steady EPS growth and demand from data centers and EVs, while Comcast faces slowing broadband.

headline: Wall Street Breakfast Podcast: Delayed Jobs Numbers Drop Today
summary: Long-delayed September nonfarm payrolls expected to be relatively steady. Netflix will keep releasing Warner Bros. films in theaters if it bought the studio. ByteDance's valuation soars.

headline: Warner Bros. Suitors Put Final Touches on Bids as Deadline Nears
summary: Comcast and Netflix are most interested in the film and TV library, which includes everything fromto Bugs Bunny.  Paramount is willing to buy the whole company, including cable channels such as CNN, TNT and the Cartoon Network.

headline: Netflix’s Warner Bros. Bid Would Include Theater Releases
summary: Warner Bros. has contractual agreements to release movies in theaters, which Netflix would honor, according to the people, who asked not to be identified revealing details of talks between the companies.  Up to now, Netflix has resisted distributing its movies in theaters, and has grown to rival Hollywood’s largest studios without doing so.  The possibility of owning Warner Bros.’ deep film library, along with the contractual obligations, has softened that opposition.
